cons: I am bored at my job and overqualified (my job only requires an associate's degree). job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Waco, TX
pros:
- Private nonprofit University
- Tuition Remission
- Competitive pay for Higher Education industry
- Christmas Holiday time off is generous
- Generous maternal and paternal leave
cons:
- June of 2020 overall compensation was reduced across the board (affected lower salary staff more due to base cost-of-living needs--they should have implemented a income tier approach, much like the federal tax-brackets.) 

- Hiring Freeze still in place (as of 01/22/2021)

- Merit increases were supposed to be revisited in January 2021 (as of 01/22/2021 still no word from upper-administraiton). 

- No Merit increases are expected in 2021-2022 academic year. 
- Salary pay-bands differ between departments (e.g. an Assistant Director in one department doing similar work to an Assistant Director in another department can have significant differences). 

- Career advancement and opportunities range widely, and is heavily dependent upon which department you find yourself in. This often times forces employees to leave departments in order to advance their careers. 

- Siloed structure of the University creates inefficiencies and frustration for students and faculty/staff.

job_title: Student Life Staff in Waco, TX
pros:
The Baylor staff  community is strong. BU students are incredible. Benefits are excellent. There is always something fun going on on a vibrant, beautiful  campus. The mix of Christian faith and Big 12 sports obviously has made for some unique challenges, but it also makes for a one-of-a-kind university. My own faith has grown considerably since going to work for Baylor. After 15 years at another "Christian" university, I've found the faith at Baylor to be very practical and hands-on. It's about relationships and caring for people. 

Middle management at Baylor (Vice Presidents, deans, AVPs, etc.) is exceptional. These leaders are hard-working and truly provide low-level guys like me with both great management and direction, but they also embody the idea of "servant leadership." I've seen the dean in my area give up nights and weekends to help and support a single student who is struggling, not letting one fall through the cracks. It's rare in higher education to find the level of personal support students get at Baylor, especially at a university this large.
cons:
As an employer, Baylor has many of the same cons as all other universities: you can make a great deal more income  in industry than higher education. Upward mobility is limited. Bureaucracy can make change come slowly. 

I enjoy the energy of working on a  college campus enough to overlook these in my own career, but they do exist at BU as much as any other university.

pros: I worked in the library system and loved it, staff were welcoming and it was a good community.  I enjoyed the work I had and would've stayed longer if I hadn't moved for family reasons. Pay was decent and benefits are excellent and the library is closed any time there's a school holiday so you get a decent number of days off aside from vacation.
cons: There's a lot of change going on in both the upper levels of leadership for the university as a whole and for the library, so there's a risk that there might be changes or downsizing in the future. Also, if you're not evangelical christian or comfortable with that kind of environment it may not be a good place to work.

pros: Lots of resources available (library research, exercise facilities, cafeterias, etc) even to lowly adjuncts and grad students. Adjunct pay is good (for what it is). Nice campus and by-&-large friendly people. Certain (younger) faculty are wonderful and helpful. Lots of activities, guest speakers, festivals, and conferences to appeal to intellectually curious learners.
cons: For those on the bottom of the hierarchy, you're treated as disposable grunts. No guarantee of classes even if you request them and if you have a higher degree than someone who's been there longer. Entrenched faculty are very coddled and able to dictate their desired courses, and little oversight for some grad faculty means they can really screw you over if they are negligent, incompetent, or malicious.

review_title: Lower pay to start than the private sector, but benefits are good.
pros: Good health and retirement benefits,good work to life ratio, free sports tickets (except football), free parking and low cost meals on campus for Faculty, Good workout facilities, people are friendly, and stress level is relatively low compared to the private sector.  Free tuition for children after 5 yrs of service. 3-4% raise annually with good performance.
cons: Starting pay is relatively low when compared to the private sector. It is the largest Baptist University in the world, so if you do not like some things being overtly spiritual, it may be a con. There could be more diversity in students and staff.

review_title: Fullfilling Career as an Academic Advisor
pros: Baylor University is a great place to work! By and large it's a place with appropriate procedures, professional support structures, and great people who want the best for you and the students. As an Academic Advisor you get to work one-on-one with students to help them achieve their academic goals. You also get to work with other administrative staff and program directors. And, a really nice perk of the job is, there's very few times where an Academic Advisor is required to work past 5:00pm.
cons: Like all University structures it's decentralized and can at times be confusing to navigate the proper procedures and channels necessary to achieve one's end goal.

review_title: Student Assistant Research and Engagement Position
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Waco, TX
pros: You learn how to do research well. The staff are very relatable and the workload is steady but not overwhelming. It is a relational job that usually allows you to meet people's needs. They have a supporting and caring culture, and pay well for an on-campus job.
cons: There are few positions so it's hard to get hired. This position often can have inconvenient hours. The future of the pay system for students is in question; they might drop to minimum wage. Expectations are likely to shift concerning various aspects of work activities on a regular basis.

pros: Baylor Catering was my first job and I was on a work-study program for it. It was easy to apply and the phone interview took a couple of minutes. All you have to be for this job is to have a love of hospitality and a willingness to work. If you have these things it will be really awesome to work at. They schedule you for a lot of hours but the job is fun once you know what you are doing and you end up getting paid for waiting around for customers to finish eating.
cons: There is nothing really bad to say about working here besides there being a lot of weird hours.

pros: Baylor has excellent resources and opportunities for graduate assistants, including full tuition, generous stipends, teaching opportunities (including serving as teacher of record), and support from the Graduate School and one's respective department. The cost of living in Waco is quite affordable, and there are good resources for families in the city.
cons: As with any large university, the administration seems to care more about maintenance of the school's reputation than admitting to error or being proactive on issues of justice. This is especially troubling since Baylor is a Christian university.

review_title: You might want to know this
pros: Great students. Friendly people. Excellent resources. Great benefits.  Great pay.  Christian environment.  Academic freedom.  Great sports teams.  Churches are getting better.  Abundant opportunities to build in-depth relationships and community.  Colleagues who care about you personally and not just professionally.
cons: Some departments may be largely research inactive and place a lot of emphasis on external collaboration.  Yearly review process in front of all departmental faculty.

pros: Extremely encouraging environment for a graduate student.  A lot of chances to work on projects you like and the freedom to explore new ideas.
cons: Relatively conservative school, so if that makes you uncomfortable, it can be a tough place to work.  That being said, most people are extremely warm and friendly as a result of the religious atmosphere.

review_title: Find the right department, and your work-study job can be great!
pros: Good to work for some of the professors, they are encouraging and helpful and want you to do your student job well. Others will demand big things with little specificity, this can be stressful. I had a very independent outside-type position and really enjoyed what I did. Others won't be as lucky and will get stuck behind a help desk providing mundane information to others.
cons: If you get a bitter secretary for your training, one wrong move will cost you in office politics, but this is the real world. That will be the case anywhere.

review_title: Lots of benefits to working here, but company culture needs adjusting
pros: Free tuition, excellent health insurance and retirement package.  Christian environment and the opportunity to work with college students can be very rewarding.
cons: Management is often promoted based on seniority, not level of competence or job skill.  There is also a culture of working on weekends or after hours.  It is not unusual to see someone in our office work 12-16 hour days.

review_title: It was a great time, though sometimes felt like I was being treated like a child.
pros: Baylor is a great school. I believe it is one that truly cares. Recently advances have been made to better compensate graduate students and bring incentives up to par.
cons: As a graduate student you sometimes treated as a child by the university. The belief that your situation is similar to that of an undergraduate and that you need constant supervision prevails.

pros: Worked in the University Advisement Office during the summer. The staff was wonderful, and extremely helpful. Really enjoyed the culture in the office. Very enjoyable place to work.
cons: I can't think of any cons. Again, the office was wonderful to work in and I really enjoyed it. They were very helpful with any questions I had and are just looking for people who will work hard and complete the tasks and assignments that they are given.

review_title: Excellent place to work and build community
pros: The faculty and staff are genuine and open, focused on providing an atmosphere for quality scholarship and personal growth. The campus itself is also beautiful and a great work environment. I worked for Baylor University Press while I was also a student at the university, and the staff were extremely flexible in allowing me to schedule work hours around my class times. After I left the university the faculty and staff were supportive in writing reference letters and recommendations for future positions and schooling.
cons: There are few cons to report.

pros:
I met some nice people there.
I enjoyed my students.
The pay and benefits were good.
If you are a conservative Southern Baptist, you would probably like it there.
cons:
It is a small minded, mean-spirited place where you have to watch your every step.
It is like going in a time-warp back to the worst of the 1950's.  I was actually told that "Baylor is not a place where women can speak up.
If you are a woman or a minority or have socially progressive views, you will probably not like it there.

pros: I worked at one of the Baylor IT departments and it was a good experience because it showed me how an IT job in industry looks like.  I got to work with people who work with IT and learned some of the ins and outs.  The staff was friendly, and I actually learned a lot.
cons: Nothing really other than I did not get many hours a week because of my schedule.  I definitely did embrace the opportunities that I got when I was working though.

job_title: Fundraising Floor Supervisor in Plano, TX
pros: GOod school to work for, multiple work study job opportunities. Would recommend to anyone to work there. Great management team within the development department
cons: Low pay for work study. 20 hour maximum for work study despite many students being able to handle more hours. Financial aid however needs work as they are not very educated on loan issues at times

review_title: Great position to work while in school
job_title: CLL Front Office Assistant in Waco, TX
pros: Tight knit community culture as everyone is a student. Scheduling is very flexible around courses and last minute changes can be made if an emergency arises. Working the front office is a great way to meet new students/people as you're the first face everyone sees as they enter the dorm/apt clubhouse.
cons: Asides the welcome week rush of students moving I don't have any complaints. Maybe the pay could have been higher but it is an easy job.

pros: I loved my three-and-a-half years working in ITS-Hardware as a computer repair student technician.  The manager and full-time people were wonderful to work with, extremely competent and professional, and understanding of a students' need for flexible hours.  Very pleasant atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes stressed-out students or faculty would make a fuss about dropping their machines off, so you might catch a bit of sass on occasion, but it is understandable.  A little patience and courtesy when dealing with these types of people can go an extremely long way!

pros:
everyone works together well
good benefits
good pay for area
the ability to collaborate and work in different environments is there but the communications between departments is lacking and therefore hurts the science in which novel ideas may be stifled or never come into fruition because they are unaware of the options
cons:
lack of variety
heavily weighted religious efforts
too many GREEK life kids
there can be some favoritism within departments which happens everywhere but I would like to think its not too bad here

review_title: Marina staff- outdoor adventure- student employment
pros: Opportunities for travel, team leadership, great hours and atmosphere. Best job on campus. People in OA are the best of all college folks.
cons: Not clear about raises, after working there three years I was never once promoted officially, and never given a raise-- even though I inquired and was eligible. no clear path for movement if your passionate about leadership experience during a college job.

pros: There's a strong familial atmosphere throughout Baylor. Obviously, the Christian foundation also makes the University a formidable place to grow and develop professionally -- with strong morals and sincere colleagues.
cons: In some cases, I have heard of a lack of upward mobility -- a bit of a glass ceiling for younger employees. It appears that Baylor values employees coming in, getting experience, leaving, and then returning.

review_title: From a longtime grad student at Baylor
pros: The best thing about working at Baylor are the people it brings together. There's something magic about the Baylor/Waco community. I don't think I'll find another community like this one.
cons: The summer is hot. There are way too many administrators. Faculty and grad students do not get paid enough for how much money the school has (evidenced by how much it's paying admin). It is also a little too family-oriented. For families this is obviously a pro. But for young, single people it can present some challenges.

pros: This job was a great learning experience for me. Fundraising over the phone between 5-9 pm is not an easy job. In fact, this may be the most challenging job I've ever had in some ways. However, I learned so much about how to talk to people, and how to sell a vision. I'm really grateful I took this job as a student at Baylor
cons: Cold calling/fundraising is a hard job, obviously. Also, working with student managers meant there was a lot of favoritism and cattiness at time.

review_title: Baylor University Student Athlete Programs Tutor
pros: Very ethical workplace.  Nice balance between between work and leisure. Christian workplace.  Very nice campus. There are also great places to eat on campus and off campus.
cons: Waco has a pretty high crime rate so sometimes it is unsafe to travel to downtown.  Very Christian oriented so if you are not Christian you might feel uncomfortable.

review_title: Baylor was a great place to work and I gain a vast amount of working experience.
pros: The people made the job. Great atmosphere and overall organizational culture. Everyone is very supportive and helpful with any situation that you go through. If you want to work at the best university in Texas, look no further.
cons: Little bit of a cramped work space. And there could be some down sides to having to work in Waco. Definitely not a deal breaker though.

pros: The job offers lots of flexibility for students who are taking classes and need a good job on the side to do.
cons: There can be months where this job can require a lot of us. You have to be willing to be committed to spending some of your weekends in the office.

pros: It is a good university with many talented and intellectual people. My professor that I worked for is very nice and helpful to me. I enjoyed working there as a graduate assistant, helped me to gain some hands on knowledge with my major and research. And the pay is reasonable.
cons: I don't see any cons during my experiences there.

pros: Get to study while working. Work directly with advisors who are good with people. Hours are great for college students.
cons: Not much to do besides study and the occasional task. Pays minimum wage and is not challenging whatsoever. Can be boring at times and keeps me from having leisure time in schedule.

review_title: Although Waco is an outstandingly insular community, working at Baylor is like a golden key that unlocks the community.
pros:
-Location-adjusted pay is outstanding (Waco has a very low cost of living).
-Access to Baylor facilities a huge plus
-Access to Baylor-oriented entertainment (sporting events, etc.)
cons:
-Low access to the world outside of Waco
-Difficult travel to/from Waco airport
-Is in Central Texas

review_title: My experience at baylor has been great, full of amazing people.
pros: There is alot of flexability in work schedules. The people you work with are very helpful and you can expect a comfortable work setting.
cons: Not much chance for advancement. I am only a tutor so I cant go much farther up. I am just filling this ou to be a member.

review_title: Very good study experience, the campus is very beautiful.
pros: beautiful campus, very good teachers and professors (most of them are christian), The lab is very good too, and  the diversity of the school is also a lightpoint. You can make lots of friends in this University.
cons: poor situation around campus, Waco is a small city. The sport facility is not enough for more and more students. Baylor is good, but do not put more hope on Waco.

pros:
Management: There are multiple superiors, and they are all eager to help you in whatever way they can.  
Fellow Employees: They pick the best of the best, so the environment is excellent to work in. 
Baylor is an excellent source to find positive moral and ethical values. It helps build your character, and shows you what a healthy work environment should look like.
cons: Scheduling was sometimes difficult, but it really seemed to always work out.

job_title: Outdoor Adventure Staff in Waco, TX
pros: There is such a positive work environment at Baylor Outdoor Adventure. Supervisors are incredibly flexible and understanding- they genuinely care about student workers. For the most part, staff get along great. I felt challenged and motivated to excel at my job. There were many opportunities for growth for driven employees.
cons: Limited opportunities for raises. There was also occasional conflict among staffmembers (I felt as thought management handled this well, but it.

pros: Baylor ECE department has been growing, now they try to hire more graduate students with steady stipend.
cons: Every school has downside. It depends on how depending your adviser is. If you are with AP, I bet he will ask more from you, which is good because you can learn a lot.

job_title: Part Time Faculty in Waco, TX
pros: Great campus, super nice people to work with, high salary, private school, good location near to Dallas and Austin, great benefits
cons: very conservative, small town! those are the only things I could say, anything else is great about this school and I love working here

pros: The research environment is becoming more competitive, and is quite collaborative. I felt very welcomed and formed good relationships with my coworkers.
cons: All the grad students are TAs, unless working specifically with a professor who provides a RA. This drastically limits the productivity of research compared to top universities.

pros: Working at Baylor is great. I love being able to work on the same campus where I go to class and thus develop professional as well as educational relationships with faculty on campus.
cons: Minimum wage is standard for student workers and the number of hours you can work each week is limited.

pros: Its a lively and energetic atmosphere filled with many great faculty and staff from the university alongside great mangagement that aids in developing young professionals.
cons: There is nothing to downplay about Baylor University. It is a great place to work with very few drawbacks and numerous opportunities.

pros: Convenient access to very good facilities for both scientific research and database management. Very  friendly colleagues and faculty always willing to help.
cons: Personal computers can only connect to internet by wi-fi, no LAN allowed. Wi-fi sometimes goes very slowly and it takes long time to display a website.

pros: Work enviroment was outstanding. Professors great to work with and always going above and beyond to help the students understand the material and master it.
cons: No cons existed outside of the normal teaching realm.  Trouble with some students, but overall the good students far out-weighed the poor. Like I said this is typical for any teaching position.

review_title: My time as a student caller
pros: The hours are manageable with regards to a student class schedule. Not very demanding job for a student.
cons: Many long hours of dialing, not too many actual phone calls. Very rarely, some calls can be rough in that the prospect doesn't want to give and just trying to get through that.

pros: Plenty of time to study while working, other OA's and CL's are always around to hang out with, residents are friendly
cons: Work gets boring, the hours can be inconvenient:  late nights and weekends, little incentive to work hard, pay is minimum wage

review_title: It is a great school. Town is small but really affordable. Pay is good enough.
pros: A very beautiful campus. Friendly people. High ranking in science(My Field). You enjoy the environment and the traditional events. The leadership is wonderful.
cons: The only bad thing is the city is a little small and there is not much fun in there as a large city. However, the university itself has many events.

pros: Great, free-going individuals to work with. I had the opportunity to work close to experienced professionals and essential do whatever I wanted to when I wasn't dedicated to a project.
cons: $15 an hour isn't bad for a student but there is an hours per week limit (10). That on top of no real advancement opportunities (essential work study) is kind of a drag.

pros: such a friendly atmosphere. I felt that the staff and faculty really cared about me. There is a general air of  positivity and compassion that I really appreciated.
cons: There are definitely certain values Baylor  holds to, and if you disagree with them strongly, you might have issues going along with rules or supporting the mission.

pros: The chances to explore the campus are wonderful. I sat in on conferences, was on the court and field for all sports games I wanted to attend, and saw parts of campus I had never seen before.
cons: The times needed to work are not concrete, since photography revolves around whatever time the events are.

review_title: Satisfied student worker in the call center
pros: Flexible scheduling, raises for every semester continuing to work, it was on-campus work study, but still a good job. Baylor treats its students well
cons: Night hours in my position so the scheduling was hard with extra curricular activities, but I really liked calling the highschoolers and encouraging them to come to Baylor. It's like being a cheerleader.

pros: Small classes with good student to professor ratio. Class to research loads were manageable most weeks other than mid term and final time. Labs were well established and easy to teach.
cons: Since the university is smaller, it is possible to get stuck being the TA in an area which you are uncomfortable with, but for the most part this does not happen.

pros: Great support from staff, good programs for students, class credit and got paid!
cons: Not the best student compensation plan, small housing/food allowance, lived with the students I was leading. This first-generation college student program was still being built, some rough patches are to be expected.

job_title: Engineering Student Worker in Waco, TX
pros:
-Flexible schedule to work with class schedule
-Flexible hours during busy project and test weeks
-Can do homework in down time at work
cons:
-hours based on seniority so first semester or so may not have the best hours
-doesn't pay more then minimum wage but this is a small price to pay compared to the benefits

review_title: Values Driven-  Consider myself lucky to have worked there
pros: The culture is fantastic. You feel united and part of a giant family! Plus the campus is beautiful! Great medical and retirement benefits as well. Such a great energy!
cons: In my particular department there was no room for growth after I hit a certain point. Further my career and experience was difficult.

pros:
Sense of personal impact on other students.
Room and Board covered.
Professional and interpersonal learning curve.
Supervisors care about subordinates' well-being.
cons:
On-Call weekends hold you hostage to the residence halls.
Interview Process is long and stressful.
Requires flexibility and the ability to handle sporadic change.

pros: Great to work with many students if you are an extroverted person (expect 30+ per session) and the supervisor is very nice and cooperative
cons: Can be quite challenging to prepare for work while keeping up one's own academics

pros: Great benefits and university perks go a long way. There was free access to the gym, discounted meals at the dining halls, university holidays and more. They do a very good job of providing for the faculty/staff.
cons: Nothing I can think of.

pros:
1. staff is very helpful and friendly 
2. the campus is very safe, don't even have to worry about leaving laptops in the library
cons:
1. Waco area has nothing to do and is totally not pedestrian friendly 
2. this university is all-Christian and lacks diversity

pros: You work for the greatest school in the nation.  You also get the honor of working for President and Chancellor Ken Starr.  The people are great and the campus is beautiful.
cons: I didn't have any negative views/thoughts while working for Baylor.  I loved every day at that school.

review_title: Under-qualified and weak leadership who are okay with status quo instead of pushing towards change.
pros: Many tangible perks, hours were consistent and always something interesting going on campus.
cons: Weak leadership without vision in departmental roles. Multiple inappropriate situations where I as a student was blamed instead of leadership taking responsibility.

review_title: Great place to work, but terrible HR
pros:
great retirement (10.8%, but no match)
generous leave policy for staff
energetic environment during the year
cons:
everything is political
the HR processes are unreasonably rigid, meaning they're built for one group but don't fit most of the staff
totally risk averse - not the place for innovators (for staff only -- faculty may be different)

pros: I worked in the law school and it was a great place to work. Leadership cares about faculty, staff, and students. There is license to be creative and invent new ways of doing things. Great people to work with.
cons: Every place has its cons, but none that are significant enough to put here.

pros:
Great hours
Great Staff
Great Environment
Good First Job
Great area
Given plenty of Work
Was able to do homework
cons: None I liked my job a lot. I was able to do work and sometimes had time to do homework. The staff was always friendly and they really seemed to appreciate me which is always nice.

pros: it was really good i really enjoyed it i would go back again. i would recommend it to anyone
cons: it was too far from my home so commute was difficult. i would go back if i lived closer

review_title: One of the few remaining Master's programs that compensates their graduate students.
pros: Fair compensation for graduate studies relative to living costs in Waco.
cons: Teaching Assistant assignments are inconsistent. Some semesters it will be a lot of work (20+ hours/wk). Others it will be an easy load.

pros: Great Community, Faculty who care about the students and each other.
cons: It operates like typical US Academia- slow to make positive change in academic programs. Focus now is more heavily on research than teaching excellence, which reduces the value of faculty who's practitioner experience lends more toward classroom usefulness.

pros: Good benefits, Lots of supervision, mediocre call volume for the area. Good place to start a career!
cons: One may find it challenging to stay occupied during the summer months when school is out. Too many Chiefs, not enough Indians. Lots of report writing !

pros:
Transparency of senior administrators & attempt to include faculty in major decision making. 
Wonderful collegiality and support within department. 
Unwavering commitment to providing a transformational university experience for students.
cons: Not enough diversity in many areas.

review_title: Very relaxed and willing to work with you.
pros: The work is not challenging, and they are very willing to try and work with your schedule because they understand your class obligations and of course your extra curricular activities.
cons: Pay isn't great, but what can you expect as a student worker?

pros: I worked as a research assistant at the Baylor University School of Law. I had a great experience with the faculty and staff as well as the HR department.
cons: The pay as a research assistant isn't great, but it was higher than minimum wage and provided much-needed supplemental income.

pros: Always have friendly faces and people willing to help you. You are never alone and help is alway near by.
cons: There are no downsides. I have never had a bad a day at work. Sure sometimes the work load can be much but thats nothing to complain about.

review_title: Poor Management - No Checks and Balances
pros: Kind people outside of department.
cons: Immediate Director, had no leadership or managment ability.

review_title: Great Place with a Great Mission
pros: Work study jobs were great professional development to accompany education.  Everything was really flexible to work around the student schedule.
cons: Many work study jobs are minimum wage, and with scheduling sometimes hours would be low.  Other than that it was great.

pros: Very flexible with hours. Very positive work environment. Management is good and makes good hiring decisions.
cons: Can only work up to 20 hours per week. Lower salary than most off campus jobs.

review_title: A review from a graduate assistant.
pros: A family, wholesome atmosphere. They have helped pay for my masters degree and I have a large and supportive networking base because of Baylor.
cons: Unfortunately, many people in leadership positions at Baylor are stuck in the past and seem to be afraid of change.

review_title: Baylor University is a dynamic place to work.
pros: The University has great facilities that are available to it's employees.  Cost of living in Waco is comparitively low.  Baylor is well-managed and seems to take good care of it's employees.
cons: It can be difficult to get in.

review_title: A good place for life-working balance
job_title: Teacher of Record in Waco, TX
pros: Good working environment, less pressure and nice people around
cons: You have to follow what you are told to do, a little bit less flexible for a teacher

pros: Good benefits and beautiful campus.
cons: Very little incentive to innovate or improve. As a result, the staff that stick around avoid showing much initiative.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Waco, TX
pros:
Challenging classes
Mentor-student relationship 
All highly educated coworkers 
Cheap housing nearby

High expectations
Mentor-student relationship
Private university students are ignorant and hard to look at

job_title: Experience and Admissions Representative in Waco, TX
pros: Working with Baylor’s visit office is like having a second family. You will never be bored in this office, but be prepared to work hard. You get what you’re willing to put into it.
cons: Lower pay than what the job probably deserves

pros: Leadership experience, social environment, good for learning time management
cons: Can lead to burn out and can affect grades. Financial compensation isn’t very much and won’t even cover the cost of books.

pros: Retirement benefits are amazing. Free tuition if you or someone in your family is looking to go to college is a really good benefit that many people take advantage of.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Waco, TX
pros: Higher than average PhD stipends, cheap cost of living.

review_title: Best place to work in the world!

pros: Super flexible work schedule, able to work around courses

review_title: I've greatly enjoyed the benefits of working on campus the past three years.
pros: Flexible work hours, some time to study and closer interaction with professors.

job_title: Student Athlete Tutor in Waco, TX
pros: Fun work environment, flexible schedule and hours

pros: People are very nice and very helpful.
cons: I'm hired by Baylor however I'm working all time remotely in another state doing research, I don't get good experience on the University itself. I don't have any comments on the Cons.

review_title: Best place to work on Baylor campus.

Tutoring helps you really learn your stuff

No potential for promotion

pros: The facilities are nice, and the people are polite and friendly. Health insurance covered for graduate students who teach or work as a research assistant.

review_title: Behind the times in communications, and ender relations

review_title: Work Here to Grow and Meet Incredible Students and Faculty

pros: Great place to be where I feel they care.

pros: Learn more about how to connect with other's nutrition needs
